If you haven‚Äôt checked the updates to our review policy, please do. I am taking over in the meantime. Our latest I Love Romance Blog review selection is The Impaler‚Äôs Wife by Autumn Bardot. What a great read! üòÄ

The test of a good book is one that successfully tells a tale from which you can‚Äôt turn away. The test of a good writer is one who constructs characters anyone can care about, even if their beliefs may not align with the reader. Suspension of disbelief, and being drawn into the fictional world is key. Bardot‚Äôs The Impaler‚Äôs Wife is one such title. This gothic romance is thrilling, with unerring historical accuracy, and a hint of the legend of Dracula which most have heard of.

I love tales about Dracula, and this one is just as fascinating. Housed in historical fiction, complete with gory descriptions of war and a tale of unrivaled passion, The Impaler‚Äôs Wife gives us a unique take on not only the legend of Dracula, but also a story of the man himself. Who is Vlad the Impaler? And, who is Ilona, the strong, amazing woman that falls for him?

As a reader, I was yanked into the tale from page one, equal parts mystified throughout, and by turns horrified yet unusually resigned to the circumstances. This book may test your faith in‚Ä¶well, everything you think you know. Bardot has an uncanny ability to make one of the most vilified historical figures utterly human. Or is he far more than that?

Ilona really comes into her own from the first time we encounter her ‚Äì and that pivotal moment when Vlad approaches her ‚Äì to the well-rounded, confident, strong female she becomes by the end of the book. I enjoyed learning about both characters.

So‚Ä¶is Dracula just a story? It is tempting to think otherwise. Bardot may make you a believer too. Take a chance on this read. You won‚Äôt be disappointed!

I give this a rating of four hearts for an outstanding, unforgettable reading experience. Fantastic job, Autumn! ‚ô•

Book Info:

A young woman is swept into a life of intrigue, revenge, passion, and betrayal when she falls for the world‚Äôs most notorious prince.

The year is 1464 and young King Matthias controls Hungary, his family, and the fate of the world‚Äôs most notorious political prisoner, Prince Vlad Dracula.

Ilona Szil√°gy, the king‚Äôs cousin, is young and ambitious. Dracula is determined to marry into the Hunyadi family. It is love at first sight, but the king has other plans. The Impaler Prince, however, never takes no for an answer.

This begins Ilona‚Äôs journey into the treacherous world of court intrigues, family betrayals, and her husband‚Äôs dark desires. Eager to become Vlad‚Äôs trusted confidante, Ilona soon discovers that marriage to a man tortured by his past comes with a price.

Woven throughout is a peek into the life and times of one of the world‚Äôs most enigmatic and maligned rulers‚Ä¶the man before the legend.

With Bardot‚Äôs decadent period detail and a cast of gritty, evocative characters, The Impaler‚Äôs Wife offers a fierce yet sensuous glimpse into the violent 15th century.

Here are some teasers!

And the book trailer‚Ä¶

Plus, an intriguing excerpt!

Prince Vlad rests his hand on the small of my back. ‚ÄúCome, Lady Ilona, look at the faces of anarchy and villainy, and see how much they resemble your friends and family.‚Äù

‚ÄúI will not.‚Äù I back away from the entrance where moans rise from the bowels of the labyrinth like a demon‚Äôs song.

‚ÄúThe choice is yours, of course.‚Äù His tone is low and gentle, but in the lamplight his stare is wolf-like.

I shift from foot to foot, look away, only to glance back. Does he hear my heart knocking against my breast? Can he smell my fear as it beads wet on my neck? Do I want to rise to this challenge? Or am I a fool for allowing him to bait me?

My fingers tighten around the lamp‚Äôs clay handle. ‚ÄúI will humor you, my lord, but only because Father taught me courage and graciousness.‚Äù

‚ÄúMih√°ly taught you well.‚Äù He holds out his hand. ‚ÄúMy lady.‚Äù

The lamp divides the darkness like a saber, each foot forward lighting our descent into hell. Ghostly groans from below seep through the rock. I sink into Vlad‚Äôs fur-lined coat as though their suffering will soak into my soul.

Vlad pauses before descending the narrow rock steps leading into the labyrinth‚Äôs deepest level. ‚ÄúAre you certain?‚Äù His eyes glint with challenge. ‚ÄúA weak constitution is nothing to be ashamed of.‚Äù

I lift my chin and glare with pretended insult. ‚ÄúI am the daughter of Michael Szil√°gyi and Margit B√°thory. Iron courage flows in my blood.‚Äù I push back my cuff and show him the blue-forked veins in my wrist. ‚ÄúI am as brave as Hadak Ura, our ancient pagan warlord.‚Äù

‚ÄúI believe you, my lady. I will not doubt again.‚Äù

The clanking chains and eerie moans get louder with each step down, the noises merging into a demonic choir like that of √ñrd√∂g‚Äôs requiem to the Underworld. My legs shake, my neck wet with icy prickles, and my skin tightens around my chest.

I lift the lamp into hell.

The circle of light shines upon a pockmarked man stretching his arm between the bars, his fingers curled like claws. ‚ÄúBless me, good sister.‚Äù

In the cell next to him, a naked wretch spits onto the ground. ‚ÄúMenj a fen√©be!‚Äù

‚ÄúI am innocent!‚Äù A third prisoner grabs the bars and presses his wild-bearded face against the iron. ‚ÄúTell His Highness there is a Turkish spy in his court. He is in danger! You must warn him!‚Äù

My head swivels toward Prince Vlad.

‚ÄúThere are always spies,‚Äù Vlad whispers.

I walk with measured pace and let the lantern reveal each doomed prisoner. Most stare, empty-eyed; the whips, chains, skin shredders, bone crushers, and strappado take away all hope and spirit. Others shout obscenities. One man kneels, hands in prayer, and mutters the Hail Mary.

The weight of their misery crashes down, squeezes my heart, and crushes my breath. This place must be worse than hell‚Äôs torments because these wretches yet live, have all their faculties! No one deserves this! It is inhumane! Sadistic and depraved!

My breath comes in shreds and clumps. I cover my nose with Prince Vlad‚Äôs cape, the stench of rotting flesh enfolding me in its putrid embrace. My pace quickens. It is time to end this test of my courage.

‚ÄúYou!‚Äù A milky-eyed wretch points to Prince Vlad and begins chanting in a foreign tongue.

Prince Vlad guides me away from the cells. ‚ÄúYou have thrice over proven your courage tonight.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat language was that man speaking?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe recites from the Corpus Hermeticum.‚Äù Dracula takes the lantern and illuminates the stairwell. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a pagan book of alchemy, astronomy, and metaphysics.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt sounded like he cursed us.‚Äù

‚ÄúPay no attention to a madman‚Äôs rants. That particular book is nothing but Egyptian and Greek nonsense.‚Äù

I tread upwards, evil‚Äôs chill clinging to my limbs. At the top, I try to purge the dungeon‚Äôs misery, malice, and madness with a long exhalation. Yet the horror sticks like nettles in my soul.

‚ÄúThis way.‚Äù I move past the dark tunnel and enter the lighted one, relieved to put space and distance between the prisoners and me.

The tunnel ends at a large grotto where Prince Vlad pauses to light the ring of torches affixed to the walls. I wait on a stone bench near the baptismal fount, sighing with relief as the golden glow of the church-like arches infuse peace into my troubled soul.

Prince Vlad sits beside me. ‚ÄúWe go from hell to heaven.‚Äù

I tuck a stray lock behind my ear. ‚ÄúThis was Father‚Äôs favorite grotto. God‚Äôs Buried Cathedral, he called it. His second favorite has a Titan-sized head emerging from the ground‚Äîlike a god got stuck in molten rock. I was only in that grotto once. It reminded me of an insect trapped in tree sap that ages to amber‚Äîthe insect forever entombed‚Äînever aging, almost alive in its resin grave.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you find that horrific or beautiful?‚Äù His eyes search mine.

‚ÄúBoth, I suppose.‚Äù My shoulders move into my sigh. ‚ÄúCaves are dreary places.‚Äù

‚ÄúI rather enjoy them. Tunnels have saved my life several times.‚Äù Dracula stands. ‚ÄúI think we are both ready for fresh air.‚Äù He offers his hand, its warmth a familiar comfort.

Together we walk through the tunnel lit by small lanterns that flicker like fireflies all the way to the exit.

Prince Vlad gives the stubborn iron-crossed door a hard yank and it groans open. Outside, a sapphire dawn drapes over Buda.

‚ÄúOn no.‚Äù My hands fly to my face. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so late it‚Äôs early.‚Äù Were we in the tunnels that long? If my aunts discover I never returned to my room‚Ä¶I spin about, my voice edged with panic. ‚ÄúI have to go back. Now.‚Äù

Vlad‚Äôs brows crease with concern. He tugs a handkerchief from his robe and touches it to my lips as though dabbing at a smudge. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs something I must do first.‚Äù He lays the linen over my lips and sets his mouth on mine.

Even through the thin fabric, his lips sear my own. I part my lips, feel the linen moisten with the breath of our lust. I collapse into him, my body sizzling with desire. I am about to rip away the fabric and taste his lips when he breaks the kiss.

Vlad Dracula steps back, the handkerchief between thumb and forefinger. ‚ÄúIf you marry Luigi della Scala, you will still be chaste.‚Äù He drags the handkerchief across his mouth. ‚ÄúI will always have this.‚Äù

Chaste? Prince Vlad just violated my heart and corrupted my flesh!

Back in my chambers, I touch my lips that still burn with the memory of our kiss‚Äîmy first kiss‚Äîand groan. Vlad Dracula used my virtue, conceit, and fears to study the labyrinth‚Äôs secrets. He took advantage of my desire for romantic adventure to learn the escape route.
